WHAT IS THE RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM?


When Congress passed the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, it required EPA to publish regulations and guidance for chemical accident prevention at facilities using extremely hazardous substances.  The Risk Management Program Rule (RMP Rule) was written to implement Section 12(r) of these amendments.  The rule, which build upon existing industry codes and standards, requires companies of all sizes that use certain flammable and toxic substances to develop a Risk Management Program which includes:

* Hazard assessment that details the potential effects of an accidental release, and accident history of the last five years, and an evaluation of worst-case and alternative accidental releases;

* Prevention program that includes safety precautions and maintenance, monitoring, and employee training measures; and

* Emergency response program that spells out emergency health care, employee training measures and procedures for informing the public and response agencies (e.g. the fire department, LEPC) should an accident occur.


By June 21, 1999, a summary of the facility's risk management program (known as a "Risk Management Plan" or "RMP") must be submitted to EPA, which will make the information publicly available.  The plans must be revised and submitted every five years.

The Risk Management Program is about reducing chemical risk at the local level.  This information helps local fire, police, and emergency response personnel (who must prepare for and respond to chemical accidents), and is useful to citizens in understanding the chemical hazards in communities.  EPA anticipates that making the RMPs available to the public stimulates communication between industry and the public to improve accident prevention and emergency response practices at the

local level.

WHY MUST HUNTINGTON WATER TREATMENT PLANT HAVE A RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM?

This plan is needed because our on-site supply of Chlorine is above the threshold limit of 2500 pounds.




HAZARD ASSESSMENT:  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY


CHLORINE


* On-site:        No accidents last five years.


* Off-site        No accidents last five years.


There were no accidental releases of Chlorine within the 5-years before submission of this Risk Management Plan.  No releases caused any of the following:

* An injury requiring medical treatment due to direct exposure.
* Death, injuries, or significant property damage.
* No known side effects.
* No on-site property damage.
* No off-site property damage.
* No sheltered-in-place order.



CHLORINE - HANDLE WITH CARE

Chlorine is commonly used in the water industry to purify water.  When handled correctly, chlorine is beneficial to the water treatment process.  When handled incorrectly, chlorine can be a deadly chemical impacting not only employee safety, but also the safety of the surrounding community.  Chlorine at the Huntington Water Treatment Plant is stored in 1-ton cylinders.  Special caution is always taken when handling chlorine, especially during the process of connecting or disconnecting chlorine cylinders.

* Information about Chlorine

Chlorine is a hazardous material that is a greenish-yellow gas at room temperature and pressure, and a liquid when stored under pressure.  Chlorine is used as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water.  Chlorine is heavier than air and will seek low-lying areas.  When combined with water or moisture, chlorine can form hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid.   Chlorine also supports combustion of certain substances.  Chlorine is also a health hazard.  For exposure to eyes or skin, flush with large amounts of water.  For inhalation exposure seek medical treatment.  MSDS sheets are on file.

* Required Personal Protective Equipment

Only properly trained and medically tested per

sonnel may respond to an emergency involving chlorine, and they must wear proper personal protective equipment.

Work on chlorine feed equipment, unloading equipment or piping may require that personnel follow proper Process Safety Management procedures.  The Supt. of Water Treatment will determine if the instance should require this procedure.

Minimum                    Maximum

Approved respirator                Self-contained Breathing Apparatus
                        (SCBA)

Clothes covering the entire body        Level A suit
(preferably impervious)    

Neoprene gloves                Neoprene glove

Neoprene boots                Neoprene boots



CHANGING CHLORINE CYLINDERS



* Make sure tank is positioned so black mark is directly center at top or bottom of tank..
* With the container in place, remove the protective hood.
* Valves should be in the vertical position, one valve over the other.
* Before removing the cap nut which covers the ton container relief valve outlet, check to be certain gas valve is closed.  Then remove nut.
* Remove any dirt that may be in the container valve or on the outlet gasket surface.
* Unscrew the yoke screw on gas feeder until the valve plate can be pushed all the way back.
* Place 1/16" thick washer over the gas inlet of the gas feeder.  Only use new washer.  Never re-use washers.  Replace the washer each time the container is changed.
* Mount gas feeder on container valve by placing the yoke over the valve.  Engage the gas inlet properly with the valve outlet, and tighten the yoke screw.  Excessive tightening will squeeze the washer out of the joint and should be avoided.
* Position strain relief, located on liquid trap of gas feeder, over lower ton container valve.
* Open gas cylinder 1/4 turn and close immediately.
* To test yoke assembly and washer valve connection for gas leak, fill a squeeze bottle 1/4 full of ammonia.  Hold below the inlet connection and squeeze.  If gas is leaking, a smoke will appear similar to cigarette smoke.  Tighten or replace washer to eliminate leak.  Repeat leak tests

at all other joints of the yoke assembly.
* Close gas cylinder valve on tank now operating.  Wait for ball in gauge to drop to zero.
* Open gas cylinder valve on new tank just hooked-up, 1/2 turn.
* Allow enough time for ball in gauge to indicate gas is feeding from new tank.
* Open gas cylinder valve on tank previously operating.
* Close gas cylinder valve on new tank.
* Make sure each dial on both tanks show green.
* Notify supervisor to order chlorine when last tank is in operation.

NOTE:     CHANGING CHLORINE CYLINDERS REQUIRES TWO
                  OPERATORS!

1. Only authorized personnel who have been instructed in chlorine safety and the use of the gas mask shall connect and disconnect the one-ton cylinders of chlorine.
2. Do not handle chlorine containers roughly; never drop containers or permit one to collide with another.
3. As soon as a container is empty and disconnected, replace the protective hood.
4. Always tag or mark empty containers at once.
5. Do not store or allow flammable materials to accumulate near the containers.



CHLORINE INHALATION - FIRST AID


The following first aid measures are recommendations from reliable sources for persons that that been exposed to high chlorine concentrations and who are in need of treatment pending medical care.

1. Remove patient at once away from the gas area preferably to a room at about 70 degrees F.
2. CALL A PHYSICIAN IMMEDIATELY.
3. Place the patient flat on his back with his back slightly elevated; supply blankets if necessary; keep patient warm and quiet, because rest is essential.
4. Splashes of liquid chlorine and chlorinated water destroy clothing and if such clothing is next to the skin, will provide irritation and chemical burns.  In such cases remove clothes.  Flush the exposed area with water if condition of patient permits it. Keep patient warm with blankets.
5. If the patient is unconscious and breathing has apparently ceased, start artificial respiration immediately.  Mouth to mouth resusci

tation or any of the approved methods may be used.
6. Oxygen administered under pressure is mandatory (when patient is breathing with difficulty).  This procedure should be continued as long as the patient shows any tendency to excessive coughing.  Instructions of the oxygen inhalator should be carefully obeyed.
7. If the patient is conscious have him drink one of these:  hot black coffee; 1/2  teaspoon essence of peppermint in 1/2  glass of hot water; a moderate dose of Bromo Seltzer.  In mild cases, milk may be given as a relief from throat irritation.  NOTHING SHOULD BE GIVEN TO A PATIENT WHO IS UNCONSCIOUS.
8. Do not give the patient alcoholic drinks, as these have harmful effects.
9. If the eyes are slightly irritated, wash them with boric acid.
10. Rest is recommended after severe chlorine exposure.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



* PURPOSE - The purpose of an emergency action plan is to protect the employees and community from serious injury, property loss, or loss of life in the event of a major disaster.  A major disaster constitutes one of the following: Fire, tornado, earthquake, a bomb threat, or a hazardous chemical spill.

* GENERAL PROCEDURES - In the event of a hazardous chemical spill or leak, namely CHLORINE, the warning will come from chlorine storage building by flashing light, and in the treatment plant the warning will come by siren.

* EMERGENCY CONTROL COMMITTEE - The following personnel will constitute the Emergency Control Committee:

Water Dept. Supt.
Safety Director

1. Report all emergencies to 911 dispatch.
2. Review nature and extent of all emergencies.
3. Assume control of all emergency actions until relieved by higher author

ity.
4. Assign tasks to personnel to carry out specific actions.
5. Order evacuation from plant if deemed necessary.
6. Take any other action necessary to protect life.
7. Annually review plan and revise as necessary.
8. Plan training exercises to test action plan.
9. Instruct personnel of their duties under this plan.

In any emergency situation, the ranking member of management present shall have final authority to coordinate procedures, and amend, modify or supersede any provisions of this plan in order to ensure employee safety.


EMERGENCY PHONE NUMBERS -    Fire            911
                        Police            911
                        Sheriff            911
                        Ambulance/EMS    911
                        LEPC            358-4870



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN, continued



* Evacuation Site - Information on evacuation will be given directly to employees should the situation warrant.

* Special Note:  In the event of a severe Chlorine leak or large release, employees are not to attempt to solve the problem.  Immediately notify those departments listed under Emergency Phone Numbers.

* Employee Training - Employee training regarding the handling of chlorine cylinders; connection of chlorine cylinders; and emergency response procedures in case of a release of chlorine will be given every three years.



HANDLING THE EMERGENCY


Scope of this plan includes:

* Chlorine release contained within the chlorine storage building and controllable by plant personnel and equipment.

* A chlorine release affecting or with the potential to affect the area surrounding the facility; such a release would require outside assistance.

1.  Planning for handling the emergency:

* Responsibility:

The Water Treatment Plant Supt. is ultimately responsible for the implementation of the plan.  He is responsible for keeping the plan current and insuring that all employees are properly trained.

2.  Any employee informing fellow workers of the chlorine release initiates the Emergency Response Plan.

3.  Assembly Area:

* Large area, second floor.
* If evacuation necessary

, notification will be given (depending on wind speed, etc.)

4. Overall Emergency Response Coordination

* Make necessary phone call to emergency personnel, 911.
* Should an emergency arise during any shift, the Supt. if to be notified immediately.
* The Supt. will upon notification coordinate the need for a rescue team with the Incident Commander.
* The Supt. will coordinate the need for an emergency repair team with the Incident Commander.
* The Supt. will coordinate the need for outside assistance and/or notification with the Incident Commander.


HANDLING THE EMERGENCY, CONTINUED



5. PHONE ANSWERING

* During any shift, the operator on duty will staff the telephone.  Any requests from the media are to be referred to the Water Supt.  If that person is unavailable, take the person's name, organization, and phone number.  Persons assigned to answering the phone are not authorized to discuss the incident with the media or with any other callers except people involved with the emergency response.  Simply state "We have had an emergency.  We are responding to it now (or it has ended).  Someone from this facility will return your call as soon as possible if you will give me your name, organization, and phone number.  I am not authorized to give you any information."  Give your name if asked.

* Media inquiries should be handled, as time permits, by the emergency response coordinator or other supervisory personnel.  When time permits, media personnel should be give background information on chlorine.  When facts are known about the incident and the cause, these should be given to the media.  Any person discussing the incident with the media must not speculate as to the cause of the incident.  If the cause is known, so advise the media.  If the cause is not known, advise the media it is under investigation.  When dealing with the media remember to be honest, courteous, straightforward and concerned.  Do not speculate.  Do not give "off the record" comments.

6. Shelte

r/Evacuation

* A decision regarding whether to evacuate or to shelter affected outside persons is a difficult one.  Generally, even a significant chlorine release is likely to last, at most, 30-40 minutes before it is contained.

Therefore, sheltering in place is the normal mode to be utilized during an emergency.  While it is unlikely that this facility could have a chlorine release requiring evacuation, nevertheless, we must be prepared for such an eventuality.  If it is anticipated that a release cannot be soon contained or is of a massive quantity, the evacuation option should be utilized.



HANDLING THE EMERGENCY, CONTINUED

* Notify the fire department and suggest that sheltering of residences for 1/2 mile be implemented.  The fire department will make the necessary notifications in accordance with the previously agreed upon sheltering plan.  Residences will be notified to shut windows and close any ventilation system and listen for further advisories.

* Notify Huntington Memorial Hospital regarding the chlorine release so they may be prepared for such people who might show up with alleged chlorine inhalation problems from within a 2 mile radius of the plant.

* Any injured employee suffering from chlorine inhalation should be sent to the hospital.  To the extent possible, the employee should be accompanied by another plant employee.  Notification to the family should be made as soon as practicable by a supervisor.

7. ALL CLEAR

* The overall emergency response coordinator is to give the all clear signal when the emergency condition is eliminated.  This notification is to be given verbally to all plant employees, any emergency responders, to affected neighbors, and, if involved, the news media.
